ripe 0.1.0
  • Reference
  • Articles
  • Get started

ripe

The goal of ripe is to create a more flexible way to rerun {magrittr} pipes.

Installation

remotes::install_github('yonicd/ripe')

Goal

We want to write the following in a shorter and more flexible way


f <- function(){
  
  stats::runif(20)%>%
    sample(10)%>%
    utils::head(5)
}

replicate(n=3,f(),simplify = FALSE)
#> [[1]]
#> [1] 0.8769399 0.4295384 0.3788314 0.9384849 0.0099595
#> 
#> [[2]]
#> [1] 0.2901681 0.2734215 0.8646582 0.2947153 0.3686175
#> 
#> [[3]]
#> [1] 0.3076415 0.6341915 0.2503614 0.1600710 0.5109676

This is better!

stats::runif(20)%>%
  sample(10)%>%
  utils::head(5)%>%
  ripe(replicate,n=4,simplify=FALSE)
#> [[1]]
#> [1] 0.192703787 0.985483787 0.428080428 0.693432509 0.007563088
#> 
#> [[2]]
#> [1] 0.5093931 0.8084108 0.7767508 0.6410062 0.3837405
#> 
#> [[3]]
#> [1] 0.1880096 0.4747303 0.2816422 0.3015278 0.6043180
#> 
#> [[4]]
#> [1] 0.07800709 0.30520355 0.89249012 0.62574955 0.87257676

Manipulate Chain Replicates

We can now manipulate the chain or move ripe around into different subsets of the chain, creating iterative replication workflows.


stats::runif(20)%>%
  #sample(10)%>%
  utils::head(5)%>%
  ripe(replicate,n=4,simplify=FALSE)
#> [[1]]
#> [1] 0.1626162 0.1694581 0.2142113 0.3297105 0.6956868
#> 
#> [[2]]
#> [1] 0.4746997 0.0368005 0.7420256 0.1952719 0.4150002
#> 
#> [[3]]
#> [1] 0.95460463 0.60474578 0.09364214 0.96106994 0.38330839
#> 
#> [[4]]
#> [1] 0.5792943 0.2630555 0.5049173 0.5151911 0.3226810

Convert Chains to Lazy Functions

You can also quickly convert the chain to a lazyeval function

f <- stats::runif(20)%>%
  sample(10)%>%
  utils::head(5)%>%
  lazy()

f()
#> [1] 0.3213823 0.6948456 0.9522991 0.5520695 0.4468634
f()
#> [1] 0.7632988 0.0643792 0.5352241 0.5513400 0.5147132
